course_title: Special Topics in Economics: Gender Economics&Women in Data
class_notes:
Gender Economics
You often hear of the gender wage gap. How big is it? What causes it?
What happens with boys and girls in early education? Are boys performing better or worse? And by how much? Does this happen everywhere in the world? Why are more women enrolling in colleges but not in the work force?
In this course we are going to start by questioning our priors on the numbers related to gender and many socio-economic characteristics. And then we will look at the data and the literature that examines these topics and answers the questions above. Students will finish this course with hands on experience looking at the literature and the data on gender economics. 
This class provides students with valuable information and eye opening facts, about the world biases that affects us all since early ages. There will be fun discussions all hands-on data analysis. 
Topics from these two interesting and fun books will be covered: 
Of boys and men by Richards Reeves 
Invisible Women by Caroline Criado Perez
course_description: Selected topics in Economics. May be repeated for credit when topic varies.
prerequisites: This course requires ECON _OX 100 or ECON 101 or ECON_OX 101 or FIN 201 AND ECON 112  or ECON_OX112 or equivalent transfer credit as a prerequisite.
instructors: Paloma Lopez de mesa Moyano - Primary Instructor
